title: Supported Models
text: Clusters: may pass cluster variables bare name, string, one-sided formula (e.g., clusters = cat_b, "cat_b", ~cat_b). DAGassist resolves within data. Fixed/Random effects: Random-effects bars (e.g., (1 | group)) fixest FE/IV tails (| fe ...) formula preserved. Difference--Differences: notation works, interaction term must included node DAG, named exactly model, set exposure. DAGassist breaks exposure missing mismatched.

title: Supported Models
code: DAGassist(     dag = dag_model,     formula = estimatr::lm_robust(         ancvs_change_1116 ~ western_belt +             unemploy_broad + black_popshare + col_popshare +             indasian_popshare + other_popshare + share_formal +             share_informal + share_traditional + afrikaans_popshare +             english_popshare + isindebele_popshare + isixhosa_popshare +             sepedi_popshare + sesotho_popshare + setswana_popshare +             signlanguage_popshare + siswati_popshare + tshivenda_popshare +             xitsonga_popshare +             latitude + longitude + latitudelongitude,         data     = df,         clusters = cat_b) )

title: Supported Models
code: DAGassist(     dag = dag_model2,     formula = fixest::feglm(         exc_eq ~ cat4_prevalence_best + nonvprotgovt + v2x_gencs +             WINGOImputed_fill + UNintervention + majpowintervention + UNwomen +              religious + ideolleft + lgt + substantive + v2x_gencl +              Krause_wpm_neg + eqgen_binary,         data = df %>% filter(interstateonly==0, inter_intrastate==0),         family = binomial("logit"),         cluster = ~cowcode     ) )

title: Supported Models
code: DAGassist(   dag = dag_model,   formula = fixest::feols(     psoe ~ time * treated2 + log_pop + no_education + growthunemployment+        men_50_rs + immigration_rs + ebal_w | province,     data = df,     cluster = ~municipality) )

title: Supported Models
code: DAGassist(dag=dag_model,           formula = lfe::felm(               share_female ~ lag_democracy_stock_poly_95 + lag_v2xcl_rol +                    lag_v2xcl_prpty + lag_v2x_rule + lag_v2x_jucon +                   lag_v2xlg_legcon + lag_v2x_corr + lag_v2clstown +                    lag_v2xcs_ccsi + lag_v2xps_party | year + country_isocode | 0 |                    country_isocode,               data=df_cross) )

title: Supported Models
code: DAGassist(     dag = dag_model,     formula = lme4::glmer(         dsu_file ~ specific + lnearnings + distortion + progress + duration +             eu + japan + mexico + korea + nonoecd +              lntotdirx + lnprod + lnpolcon + active301 +             (1 | isic3_4dig),         data   = df,         family = binomial(link = "logit"),         control = glmerControl(optimizer = "bobyqa")) )

title: Supported Models
code: DAGassist(     dag = dag_model,     formula = lmerTest::lmer(         ekloges_PERCENTAGE_May_2012_GD ~ ekloges_PERCENTAGE_2009_GD +             N_AntifaEvent_notzero2_Oc09_May12 + avg_age + log_population  +             prop_ksenoi + (1|code_perif),          data=dta))

title: Supported Models
code: DAGassist(   dag = dag_model,   formula = MASS::glm.nb(     protestcount ~ civilcas_percapita + sigact_percapita + log_pop + shiapop_perc       kurdpop_perc + urban + totaloilvolx + lognearestcity + feb2011 + nov2010 +       laggedprotestcount + illiterate + incomequintilelowest +        incomequintilehighest + urate + powercontinuous,     data = iraqevents_timeseries_small,     control = glm.control(maxit = 50),     link = "log") )

title: Supported Models
code: DAGassist(   dag = dag_model,   formula = stats::lm(     restraint ~ nonvio2 + prime_frat + prime_future + prime_RU + prime_UN +        oppose92coup2 + civwar + islamist + supp_sharia + active + conscript +        soldier + junoff + senoff + branch2 + train_west + train_russia +        train_china + young + sex + edu + urban_area + employed + student +        arabic + econ1 + corr1 + dem + supp_opp_parties + continue + protested +        preboutef + post_exp + mon + factor(fgov),      data=data) )

title: DAGassist in the R DAG Ecosystem
text: article explains broader R DAG ecosystem positions DAGassist within . also explains dependencies necessary maximize DAGassist’s functionality. dagitty DAG specification reasoning ggdag visualize DAGs modelsummary format regression tables broom tidy models (coefs & goodness--fit) writexl export multi‑sheet Excel workbooks rmarkdown render shareable docs (HTML/Word/PDF) embed DAGassist outputs

previous_headings: Introduction > The Differences Between dagitty, ggdag, and DAGassist
title: DAGassist in the R DAG Ecosystem
text: core DAG toolkit R. Creates actual DAG object ggdag DAGassist use. dagitty::adjustmentSets() scans dagitty object identify adjustment sets. dagitty::isAcyclic() verifies acyclicity. dagitty::findCycle() identifies cyclical variable relationships. Making DAG dagitty:
code: #via dagitty library(dagitty)  dag_model <- dagitty('dag {     EffectiveN_electoral     Gov_effectiveness_0_5     LR_Polarization_perceived     PID_noleaners [exposure]     Presidentialsystem     VoterAPI_Party [outcome]     Year_0     EffectiveN_electoral -> VoterAPI_Party     Gov_effectiveness_0_5 -> VoterAPI_Party     LR_Polarization_perceived -> VoterAPI_Party     PID_noleaners -> LR_Polarization_perceived     PID_noleaners -> VoterAPI_Party     Presidentialsystem -> EffectiveN_electoral     Presidentialsystem -> VoterAPI_Party     Year_0 -> PID_noleaners     Year_0 -> VoterAPI_Party }')

previous_headings: Introduction > The Differences Between dagitty, ggdag, and DAGassist
title: DAGassist in the R DAG Ecosystem
text: visualization layer DAGs. Also provides intuitive way make dagitty objects. Making identical DAG ggdag:
code: #via ggdag library(ggdag)  dag_model <- dagify(   VoterAPI_Party  ~ PID_noleaners + LR_Polarization_perceived +     Gov_effectiveness_0_5 + EffectiveN_electoral + Presidentialsystem,        LR_Polarization_perceived ~  PID_noleaners,      EffectiveN_electoral ~ Presidentialsystem,        exposure = "PID_noleaners",   outcome = "VoterAPI_Party" )

previous_headings: Introduction > The Differences Between dagitty, ggdag, and DAGassist
title: DAGassist in the R DAG Ecosystem
text: glue DAG models regressions. Uses dagitty logic classify causal relationships embedded DAG. Identifies relationships implications covariate selection concise, publication-grade report. uses dagitty logic derive minimal canonical adjustment sets, according criteria: Note: ✓ = adjust; ✗ = adjust. may multiple minimal sets; canonical set unique.

title: Getting the Most out of DAGassist Using Parameters
text: DAGassist() meant simple easy use, features can enjoyed via simple two-parameter argument: also offers several parameters specific applications. control DAG evaluated (imply, eval_all), results print (show, labels, omit_factors, omit_intercept, verbose), modeling engine use (engine, engine_args), output format write (type, ). vignette walks small examples.
code: library(DAGassist) library(dagitty)  DAGassist(   dag = your_dag_model,   formula = your_regression_call )

title: Getting the Most out of DAGassist Using Parameters
text: formula can standard formula + data regression call, DAGassist impute necessary information, three separate formula, data, engine arguments. two formulas print identical output.
code: #imputed formula DAGassist(   #implies the exposure and outcome from the dagitty object   dag = dag_model,    #implies the engine, formula, and data from the regression call   formula = lm(Y ~ X + C, data=df)  )  #plain formula DAGassist(   dag = dag_model,   engine = stats::lm, #stats::lm is the default engine arg   formula = Y ~ X + C,   data = df,   exposure = "X",   outcome = "Y" )

what: imply: evaluate on only mentioned variables vs the full DAG
title: Getting the Most out of DAGassist Using Parameters
text: imply = FALSE (default): prune DAG just exposure, outcome, RHS variables; roles/sets computed pruned graph. imply = TRUE: evaluate full DAG allow DAG-implied controls enter minimal/canonical sets (’ll told ’s added).
code: #pruned-to-formula DAG DAGassist(dag = dag_model, formula = Y ~ X + C, data = df, imply = FALSE, show = "roles") #> DAGassist Report:  #>  #> Roles: #> variable  role       X  Y  conf  med  col  dOut  dMed  dCol  dConfOn  dConfOff  NCT  NCO #> X         exposure   x                                                                   #> Y         outcome       x                                                                #> C         collider                    x    x                                             #>  #>  (!) Bad controls in your formula: {C}  #full-DAG evaluation DAGassist(dag = dag_model, formula = Y ~ X + C, data = df, imply = TRUE,  show = "roles") #> DAGassist Report:  #>  #> Roles: #> variable  role        X  Y  conf  med  col  dOut  dMed  dCol  dConfOn  dConfOff  NCT  NCO #> X         exposure    x                                                                   #> Y         outcome        x                                                                #> Z         confounder        x                                                             #> M         mediator                x                                                       #> C         collider                     x    x     x                                       #> A         nco                                                                         x   #> B         nco                                                                         x   #>  #>  (!) Bad controls in your formula: {C}

what: eval_all: keep non-DAG RHS terms in derived models
title: Getting the Most out of DAGassist Using Parameters
text: Sometimes RHS terms aren’t DAG nodes (e.g., fixed effects via (region), factor expansions, interactions, splines). eval_all decides whether non-DAG terms kept minimal/canonical formulas. - eval_all = FALSE (default): drop RHS terms present DAG nodes derived formulas. - eval_all = TRUE: keep original RHS terms aren’t DAG nodes (e.g., fixed effects), addition DAG-based controls.
code: DAGassist(     dag = dag_model,     formula = fixest::feols(Y ~ X + C + fixest::i(region), data = df),     imply = TRUE,     eval_all = TRUE     )

title: Getting the Most out of DAGassist Using Parameters
text: “” (default): roles grid + model comparison “roles”: just roles/flags table “models”: just model comparison
code: # just the roles table DAGassist(dag = dag_model, formula = Y ~ X + Z + C, data = df, show = "roles") #just the model comparison DAGassist(dag = dag_model, formula = Y ~ X + Z + C, data = df, show = "models")

title: Getting the Most out of DAGassist Using Parameters
text: Provide named character vector small data frame. Note label parameter uses modelsummary() coef_rename logic, incomplete label list throw errors.
code: labs <- list(   X = "Exposure",   Y = "Outcome",   C = "Collider" )  DAGassist(   dag = dag_model, formula = lm(Y ~ X + C, data = df),   show = "roles", labels = labs ) #> DAGassist Report:  #>  #> Roles: #> variable  role       X  Y  conf  med  col  dOut  dMed  dCol  dConfOn  dConfOff  NCT  NCO #> Exposure  exposure   x                                                                   #> Outcome   outcome       x                                                                #> Collider  collider                    x    x                                             #>  #>  (!) Bad controls in your formula: {C}

title: Getting the Most out of DAGassist Using Parameters
text: flags suppress rows printed model comparison. remove terms estimation. omit_factors particular useful conserving space report, reports factors included can hundreds rows.
code: DAGassist(     dag = dag_model,     formula = fixest::feols(Y ~ X + Z + i(region), data = df),     omit_intercept = TRUE, omit_factors = TRUE # both TRUE by default   )

what: bivariate: include a no-covariate comparison column
title: Getting the Most out of DAGassist Using Parameters
text: Include Y ~ X column readers want raw association. bivariate = FALSE default.

title: Getting the Most out of DAGassist Using Parameters
text: verbose = TRUE (default) prints helpful notes (added/dropped, derived formulas). Set FALSE quieter console.
code: DAGassist(dag = dag_model, formula = Y ~ X + Z + C, data = df, verbose = FALSE)

title: Getting Started with Report Creation
text: vignette explains make publication-grade DAGassist reports LaTeX, Word, Excel, plaintext. Since package’s primary utility robustness check observational studies, functionality revolves around creating reports.

title: Getting Started with Report Creation
code: # install development release from github install.packages("pak") pak::pak("grahamgoff/DAGassist")  # or, install stable release from CRAN install.packages("DAGassist")  #load DAGassist library(DAGassist)

title: Getting Started with Report Creation
text: addition loading DAGassist, load following baseline packages: LaTeX uses broom fallback report generation knitr build intermediate .md Word plaintext report generation. rmarkdown convert .md files .docx files Word report generation. writexl export Excel files. Essentially, export: LaTeX needs modelsummary Excel needs modelsummary writexl plaintext needs modelsummary knitr Word needs modelsummary, knitr, rmarkdown
code: #load libraries to help export library(modelsummary) library(writexl) library(knitr) library(rmarkdown)

title: Getting Started with Report Creation
text: data, simulates DAG relationships:

title: Getting Started with Report Creation
text: Suppose wrote article uses model original main finding, want ensure specification captures total effect D Y, without mediator collider bias. DAGassist can generate report assessing causal roles variables original. DAGassist Report:
code: original <- lm(Y ~ D + G + H + F + A + B + C, data = df) DAGassist(dag = dag_model, #specify a dagitty or ggdag object           formula = lm(Y ~ D + G + H + F + A + B + C, data = df), #provide your formula           type = "text", #output type           out = out_txt) #a temporary directory, for the purpose of this vignette  cat(readLines(out_txt), sep = "\n") # show the output

title: Getting Started with Report Creation
text: p-value legend: + < 0.1, * < 0.05, ** < 0.01, *** < 0.001. Controls (minimal): {F, H}. Controls (canonical): {, B, C, F, G, H}.

title: Getting Started with Report Creation
text: Sometimes need one part report. Use show argument generate just roles grid just model comparison: show = "roles" – produce DAG-based roles table. model fitted, formula data required. ideal regression engine isn’t supported simply want audit variable roles. show = "models" – produce model comparison (Original / Minimal / Canonical). Requires model specification (either formula single engine call); roles table printed.

title: Getting Started with Report Creation
code: DAGassist(dag = dag_model,           show = "roles") #> DAGassist Report:  #>  #> Roles: #> variable  role        X  Y  conf  med  col  dOut  dMed  dCol  dConfOn  dConfOff  NCT  NCO #> D         exposure    x                                                                   #> Y         outcome        x                                                                #> A         confounder        x                                 x                           #> B         confounder        x                                                             #> C         confounder        x                                                             #> F         confounder        x                                                             #> G         nco                                                                         x   #> H         nco                                                 x                       x

what: Making a dot‑whisker plot of the key coefficient
title: Getting Started with Report Creation
code: # Returns a ggplot object (prints if out = NULL; saves if out is a file path) DAGassist(dag = dag_model,           formula = lm(Y ~ D + G + H + F + A + B + C, data = df),           type = "dotwhisker")

title: Getting Started with Report Creation
text: default, DAGassist() reports canonical adjustment set, excludes non-admissible adjustments (colliders, mediators, descendants). Sometimes, users may want see canonical set minus certain classes “neutral” controls, per Hunermund, Louw Ronkko (2025). exclude = argument enables selective exclusion neutral controls. - exclude = "nct" drops neutral controls treatment - exclude = "nco" drops neutral controls outcome

title: DAGassist in 10 minutes
text: go dagitty DAG + formula compact report interpret report, variable categories comparison models mean export LaTeX / Word / Excel / text

title: DAGassist in 10 minutes
code: library(DAGassist) # load helper libraries library(modelsummary) library(dagitty)

title: DAGassist in 10 minutes
code: n <- 500 Z <- rnorm(n) A <- rnorm(n) X <- 0.6*Z + rnorm(n) M <- 0.5*X + 0.3*Z + rnorm(n) Y <- 1.0*X + 0.0*M + 0.5*Z + rnorm(n) df <- data.frame(Y, X, M, Z, A)  dag_model <- dagitty('   dag {     Z -> X     Z -> Y     A -> Y     X -> M     X -> Y     M -> Y     X [exposure]     Y [outcome]   }')

what: Generate a console report with DAGassist
title: DAGassist in 10 minutes
text: See Getting Started vignette guide using different parameters get DAGassist. purpose tutorial, keep simple. See Supported Models vignette documentation engines DAGassist supports. Since DAGassist model-agnostic, engine accepts standard formula + data interface, usually work. Interpreting output: X treatment / independent variable / exposure. Y outcome / dependent variable. conf stands confounder, common cause X Y. Confounders create spurious association X Y, must adjusted . med stands mediator, variable lies path X Y, transmit effect X Y. One adjust mediators one wants estimate total effect X Y. col stands collider, direct common descendant X Y. Colliders already block paths, adjusting opens spurious association X Y. IO stands intermediate outcome, descendant Y, introduces bias adjusted . dMed / Dmediator stands descendant mediator, adjusted estimating total effect. dCol / Dcollider stands descendant collider. Adjusting descendant collider opens spurious association X Y. variables, affect outcome, fit previous definitions. included canonical model can safely included controls, omitted minimal model inclusion strictly necessary. Since variables’ effects generally neutral, usually best use minimal adjustment set baseline model. MODEL COMPARISON: Minimal smallest adjustment set necessary close back-door paths independent dependent variable. minimal set includes confounders controls. Canonical largest permissible adjustment set. Essentially, canonical set contains control variables confounders, mediators, intermediate outcomes, descendants mediatiors, descendants colliders.

title: DAGassist in 10 minutes
text: See Making Reports vignette detailed information producing publication-quality DAGassist reports LaTex, Word, Excel, plaintext. Since DAGassist designed make appendix robustness checks, example output report LaTeX. Optionally, users can generate visual output via dotwhisker plots:
code: #initialize a temporary path out_tex <- file.path(tempdir(), "dagassist_report.tex")  DAGassist(   dag = dag_model,   formula = lm(Y ~ X + M + Z + A, data = df),   type = "latex",    out = out_tex) #put your output directory and file name here  cat(readLines(out_tex, n = 15), sep = "\n") # briefly show the output #> % --------------------- DAGassist LaTeX fragment --------------------- #> % Requires: \usepackage{tabularray} \UseTblrLibrary{booktabs,siunitx,talltblr} #> \begingroup\footnotesize #> \begingroup\setlength{\emergencystretch}{3em} #> % needs \usepackage{graphicx} for \rotatebox #> \begin{longtblr}[presep=0pt, postsep=0pt, caption={DAGassist Report:}, label={tab:dagassist}]% #> {width=\textwidth,colsep=1.5pt,rowsep=0pt,abovesep=0pt,belowsep=0pt,column{3}={colsep=6pt},colspec={X[35,l]X[15,l]X[8,c]X[8,c]X[8,c]X[8,c]X[8,c]X[8,c]X[8,c]X[8,c]X[8,c]X[8,c]X[8,c]X[8,c]}} #> \toprule #> Variable & Role & \rotatebox[origin=c]{60}{X} & \rotatebox[origin=c]{60}{Y} & \rotatebox[origin=c]{60}{CON} & \rotatebox[origin=c]{60}{MED} & \rotatebox[origin=c]{60}{COL} & \rotatebox[origin=c]{60}{dOut} & \rotatebox[origin=c]{60}{dMed} & \rotatebox[origin=c]{60}{dCol} & \rotatebox[origin=c]{60}{dConfOn} & \rotatebox[origin=c]{60}{dConfOff} & \rotatebox[origin=c]{60}{NCT} & \rotatebox[origin=c]{60}{NCO} \\ #> \midrule #> A & nco &  &  &  &  &  &  &  &  &  &  &  & x \\ #> M & mediator &  &  &  & x &  &  &  &  &  &  &  &  \\ #> X & exposure & x &  &  &  &  &  &  &  &  &  &  &  \\ #> Y & outcome &  & x &  &  &  &  &  &  &  &  &  &  \\ #> Z & confounder &  &  & x &  &  &  &  &  &  &  &  &  \\ DAGassist(dag = dag_model,           formula = lm(Y ~ X + M + Z + A, data = df),           type = "dotwhisker")

title: Counterfactuals and Relevant Terms
text: Questions causality predominate throughout natural social sciences (Pearl 2009). However, observational data limited ability demonstrate causality “…one can never observe potential outcome treatment state observed control state, one can never observe potential outcome control state observed treatment state” (Morgan Winship 2015, 45). Holland (1986) describes fundamental problem causal inference. counterfactual model provides approaches inferring causal relationships observational data. article provides concise explanation ideas applications.

title: Counterfactuals and Relevant Terms
text: (counterfactual model? basic principals? focused aspects encoded DAGs) back-door adjustment criterion two main components: ``…conditioning variables lie back-door paths can effective strategy identify causal effect’’ (Morgan Winship 2015, 116). ``…set conditioning variables blocks back-door paths, analyst must varify variables within conditioning set block causal effect interest otherwise mistakenly adjust away’’ (Morgan Winship 2015, 117). Essentially, researchers condition set variables enables close back-door paths. SUTVA: “SUTVA simply priori assumption value Y unit uu exposed treatment tt matter mechanism used assign treatment tt unit uu matter treatnebts units receive” (Morgan Winship 2015, 48). ceteris paribus assumptions: “facile ceteris paribus assumption invoked relieve analyst discuss contrasts nearly certain occur time, posited causal states may open charge improbable ill-defined justify pursuit causal analysis based causal analysis based ” (Morgan Winship 2015, 43).

title: Counterfactuals and Relevant Terms
text: (look kitchen sink regressions table 2 fallacies) Covariate adjustment common method inferring causality observational data. Many empirical practitioners use covariate adjustment reduce variance outcome interest, assumption larger adjustment sets increase precision. extensive growing body literature identifies shortcomings approach. Indiscriminate adjustment may lead collider bias improper representation causal interpretation multivariate models’ control variables lead table 2 fallacy. following subsection explains pitfalls.

title: Counterfactuals and Relevant Terms
text: (DAGs? define elements.) Basic Elements Causal Graphs: “Causal effects represented directed edges → (.e., single-headed arrows), edge one node another signifies variable origin directed edge causes variable terminus. ‘directed’ edges give graphs composed nodes single-headed arrows general label ‘directed graphs’” (Morgan Winship 2015, 79–80). “path sequence edges pointing direction connects one variable another’’ (Morgan Winship 2015, 80). “directed path path edges point direction” (Morgan Winship 2015, 80). “variable descendant another variable can reached direct path” (Morgan Winship 2015, 80). “importantly, directed paths length one, →B, variable AA parent variable BB child” (Morgan Winship 2015, 80).

title: Authors and Citation
text: Graham Goff. Author, maintainer. Michael Denly. Author.

title: Authors and Citation
text: Goff G, Denly M (2025). DAGassist: Test Robustness Directed Acyclic Graphs. R package version 0.2.5, https://github.com/grahamgoff/DAGassist.
code: @Manual{,   title = {DAGassist: Test Robustness with Directed Acyclic Graphs},   author = {Graham Goff and Michael Denly},   year = {2025},   note = {R package version 0.2.5},   url = {https://github.com/grahamgoff/DAGassist}, }

what: Test Robustness with Directed Acyclic Graphs
title: Test Robustness with Directed Acyclic Graphs
text: --one DAG-driven robustness check. Classify variables causal role, compute smallest largest permissible back-door adjustment sets, compare significance models. See Quick Tour vignette 10 minute start--finish guide use DAGassist identify causal roles, create reports, interpret results. See Making Reports vignette details producing publication-quality DAGassist reports LaTex, Word, Excel, plain text. See Parameter Guide vignette examples get DAGassist. See Supported Models vignette documentation engines DAGassist supports. See Ecosystem Guide DAGassist fits R DAG ecosystem—diagram packages integrates .

title: Test Robustness with Directed Acyclic Graphs
text: can install DAGassist : can install development version GitHub :
code: install.packages("DAGassist") library(DAGassist) # install.packages("devtools") devtools::install_github("grahamgoff/DAGassist")

title: Test Robustness with Directed Acyclic Graphs
text: Simply provide dagitty() object regression call DAGassist create report classifying variables causal role, compare specified regression minimal canonical models. Optionally, users can generate visual output via dotwhisker plots:

what: Generate a (console/LaTeX/word/excel/txt) report classifying nodes and comparing models — DAGassist
title: Generate a (console/LaTeX/word/excel/txt) report classifying nodes and comparing models — DAGassist
text: DAGassist() validates DAG + model specification, classifies node roles, builds minimal canonical adjustment sets, fits comparable models, renders compact report several formats (console, LaTeX fragment, DOCX, XLSX, plain text). also supports passing single engine call (e.g. feols(Y ~ X + Z | fe, data = df)) instead plain formula.

title: Generate a (console/LaTeX/word/excel/txt) report classifying nodes and comparing models — DAGassist
code: DAGassist(   dag,   formula = NULL,   data = NULL,   exposure,   outcome,   engine = stats::lm,   labels = NULL,   verbose = TRUE,   type = c("console", "latex", "word", "docx", "excel", "xlsx", "text", "txt", "dwplot",     "dotwhisker"),   show = c("all", "roles", "models"),   out = NULL,   imply = FALSE,   eval_all = FALSE,   exclude = NULL,   omit_intercept = TRUE,   omit_factors = TRUE,   bivariate = FALSE,   engine_args = list() )

title: Generate a (console/LaTeX/word/excel/txt) report classifying nodes and comparing models — DAGassist
text: dag dagitty object (see dagitty::dagitty()). formula Either () standard model formula Y ~ X + ..., (b) single engine call feols(Y ~ X + Z | fe, data = df, ...). engine call provided, engine, data, extra arguments automatically extracted call. data data.frame (compatible, e.g. tibble). Optional supplied via engine call formula. exposure Optional character scalar; missing/empty, inferred DAG (must unique). outcome Optional character scalar; missing/empty, inferred DAG (must unique). engine Modeling function, default stats::lm. Ignored formula single engine call (case function taken call). labels Optional variable labels (named character vector data.frame). verbose Logical (default TRUE). Controls verbosity console printer (formulas + notes). type Output type. One "console" (default), "latex"/"docx"/"word", "excel"/"xlsx", "text"/"txt", plotting types "dwplot"/"dotwhisker". type = "latex", = supplied, LaTeX fragment printed console instead written disk. show sections include output. One "" (default), "roles" (roles grid), "models" (model comparison table/plot). makes possible generate export just roles just comparisons. Output file path non-console types: type="latex": LaTeX fragment written (usually .tex); omitted, fragment printed console. type="docx"/"word": Word (.docx) file written . type="excel"/"xlsx": Excel (.xlsx) file written . type="text"/"txt": plain-text file written . Ignored type="console" plotting types. imply Logical; default FALSE. Evaluation scope. FALSE (default): restrict DAG evaluation variables named formula (prune DAG exposure, outcome, RHS terms). Roles/sets/bad-controls computed pruned graph, roles table shows variables. Essentially, fits DAG formula. TRUE: evaluate full DAG allow DAG-implied controls minimal/canonical sets. roles table shows DAG nodes, printout notes variables added beyond RHS. Essentially, fits formula DAG. eval_all Logical; default FALSE.  TRUE, keep original RHS terms DAG (e.g., fixed effects, interactions, splines, convenience covariates) minimal canonical formulas. FALSE (default), RHS terms present DAG nodes dropped derived formulas. exclude Optional character vector remove neutral controls canonical set. Recognized values "nct" (drop neutral--treatment controls) "nco" (drop neutral--outcome controls). can supply one , e.g. exclude = c("nco", "nct"); requested variant fitted shown separate "Canon. (-...)" column console/model exports. omit_intercept Logical; drop intercept rows model comparison display (default TRUE). omit_factors Logical; drop factor-level rows model comparison display (default TRUE). parameter suppresses factor output–still included regression. bivariate Logical; TRUE, include bivariate (exposure-) specification comparison table addition user's original DAG-derived models. engine_args Named list extra arguments forwarded engine(...). formula engine call, arguments call merged engine_args (call values take precedence).

title: Generate a (console/LaTeX/word/excel/txt) report classifying nodes and comparing models — DAGassist
text: object class "DAGassist_report", invisibly file plot outputs, printed type="console". list contains: validation - result validate_spec(...) verifies acyclicity X/Y declarations. roles - raw roles data.frame classify_nodes(...) (logic columns). roles_display - roles grid labeling/renaming exporters. bad_in_user - variables user's RHS MED/COL/dOut/dMed/dCol. controls_minimal - (legacy) one minimal set (character vector). controls_minimal_all - list minimal sets (character vectors). controls_canonical - canonical set (character vector; may empty). controls_canonical_excl - named list filtered canonical sets (e.g. $nco, $nct) exclude used. formulas - list original, minimal, minimal_list, canonical, filtered canonical formulas. models - list fitted models original, minimal, minimal_list, canonical, filtered canonical models. verbose, imply - flags provided.

title: Generate a (console/LaTeX/word/excel/txt) report classifying nodes and comparing models — DAGassist
text: addition tabular export formats, can create dot-whisker plot (via type = "dwplot" type = "dotwhisker") model comparison. Engine-call parsing. formula call (e.g., feols(Y ~ X | fe, data=df)), DAGassist extracts engine function, formula, data argument, additional engine arguments directly call; merged engine/engine_args pass explicitly (call arguments win). Fixest tails. engines like fixest use | denote FE/IV parts, DAGassist preserves | ... tail constructing minimal/canonical formulas (e.g., Y ~ X + controls | fe | iv(...)). Roles grid. roles table displays short headers: X (exposure), Y (outcome), CON (confounder), MED (mediator), COL (collider), dOut (proper descendant Y), dMed (proper descendant mediator), dCol (proper descendant collider), dConfOn (descendant confounder back-door path), dConfOff (descendant confounder back-door path), NCT (neutral control treatment), NCO (neutral control outcome). extra flags used () warn bad controls, (ii) build filtered canonical sets “Canonical (–NCO)” export. Bad controls. total-effect estimation, DAGassist flags bad controls variables MED, COL, dOut, dMed, dCol. warned console omitted model-comparison table. Valid confounders (pre-treatment) eligible minimal/canonical adjustment sets. Output types. console prints roles, adjustment sets, formulas (verbose), compact model comparison (using {modelsummary} available, falling back gracefully otherwise). latex writes prints LaTeX fragment can \\input{} paper — uses tabularray long tables include requested Canon. (-NCO / -NCT) variants. docx/word writes Word doc (respects options(DAGassist.ref_docx=...) set). excel/xlsx writes Excel workbook tidy tables. text/txt writes plain-text report logs/notes. dwplot/dotwhisker produces dot-whisker visualization fitted models. Dependencies. Core requires {dagitty}. Optional enhancements: {modelsummary} (pretty tables), {broom} (fallback tidying), {rmarkdown} + Pandoc (DOCX), {writexl} (XLSX), {dotwhisker}/{ggplot2} plotting.

title: Generate a (console/LaTeX/word/excel/txt) report classifying nodes and comparing models — DAGassist
text: See vignette articles worked examples generating roles-, models-, LaTeX/Word/Excel reports. Model Comparison: Minimal - smallest adjustment set blocks back-door paths (confounders ). Canonical - largest permissible set: includes controls MED, COL, dOut, dMed, dCol. variables may appear .

title: Generate a (console/LaTeX/word/excel/txt) report classifying nodes and comparing models — DAGassist
text: exposure/outcome inferred uniquely, function stops clear message. Fitting errors (e.g., FE collinearity) captured displayed comparisons without aborting whole pipeline.

title: Generate a (console/LaTeX/word/excel/txt) report classifying nodes and comparing models — DAGassist
code: # generate a console DAGassist report DAGassist(dag = g, formula = lm(Y ~ X + Z + C + M, data = df)) #> DAGassist Report:  #>  #> Roles: #> variable  role        X  Y  conf  med  col  dOut  dMed  dCol  dConfOn  dConfOff  NCT  NCO #> X         exposure    x                                                                   #> Y         outcome        x                                                                #> Z         confounder        x                                                             #> M         mediator                x                                                       #> C         collider                     x    x     x                                       #>  #>  (!) Bad controls in your formula: {C, M} #> Minimal controls 1: {Z} #> Canonical controls: {Z} #>  #> Formulas: #>   original:  Y ~ X + Z + C + M #>  #> Model comparison: #>  #> +---+----------+-----------+-----------+ #> |   | Original | Minimal 1 | Canonical | #> +===+==========+===========+===========+ #> | X | 0.467*** | 1.306***  | 1.306***  | #> +---+----------+-----------+-----------+ #> |   | (0.122)  | (0.098)   | (0.098)   | #> +---+----------+-----------+-----------+ #> | Z | 0.185+   | 0.235+    | 0.235+    | #> +---+----------+-----------+-----------+ #> |   | (0.102)  | (0.127)   | (0.127)   | #> +---+----------+-----------+-----------+ #> | C | 0.368*** |           |           | #> +---+----------+-----------+-----------+ #> |   | (0.076)  |           |           | #> +---+----------+-----------+-----------+ #> | M | 0.512*** |           |           | #> +---+----------+-----------+-----------+ #> |   | (0.077)  |           |           | #> +===+==========+===========+===========+ #> | + p < 0.1, * p < 0.05, ** p < 0.01,  | #> | *** p < 0.001                        | #> +===+==========+===========+===========+   # generate a LaTeX DAGassist report # \donttest{ DAGassist(dag = g, formula = lm(Y ~ X + Z + C + M, data = df),           type = "latex", out = file.path(tempdir(), "frag.tex")) # } # generate just the roles table in the console DAGassist(dag = g, show = "roles") #> DAGassist Report:  #>  #> Roles: #> variable  role        X  Y  conf  med  col  dOut  dMed  dCol  dConfOn  dConfOff  NCT  NCO #> X         exposure    x                                                                   #> Y         outcome        x                                                                #> Z         confounder        x                                                             #> M         mediator                x                                                       #> C         collider                     x    x     x                                       #> A         nco                                                                         x   #> B         nco                                                                         x

what: flag bad controls (mediator/collider/desc of Y) among a candidate set — bad_controls_in
title: flag bad controls (mediator/collider/desc of Y) among a candidate set — bad_controls_in
text: flag bad controls (mediator/collider/desc Y) among candidate set

title: flag bad controls (mediator/collider/desc of Y) among a candidate set — bad_controls_in
code: bad_controls_in(dag, controls, exposure, outcome)

title: flag bad controls (mediator/collider/desc of Y) among a candidate set — bad_controls_in
text: dag dagitty DAG object. controls Character vector variable names. exposure Character; exposure node name (X). outcome Character; outcome node name (Y).

title: flag bad controls (mediator/collider/desc of Y) among a candidate set — bad_controls_in
text: character vector (possibly empty) containing elements controls identified "bad controls". essentially inverse pick_minimal_controls(), returns bad controls, rather minimal/canonical set good controls

title: flag bad controls (mediator/collider/desc of Y) among a candidate set — bad_controls_in
code: d <- ggdag::dagify( Y ~ X + M + Z, M ~ X + Z, C ~ X + Y, exposure = "X", outcome = "Y") # M: mediator / Z: confounder / C: collider  # hypothetical candidate controls controls <- c("Z", "M", "C")  # Flag controls that would bias the total effect of X on Y: bad_controls_in(d, controls = c("Z","M","C"), exposure = "X", outcome = "Y") #> [1] "M" "C"  # expected: c("M", "C")  # mediator & collider are "bad controls"; Z is OK

title: Classify DAG nodes — classify_nodes
text: Labels node one : exposure, outcome, confounder, mediator, collider, descendant_of_outcome, .

title: Classify DAG nodes — classify_nodes
code: classify_nodes(dag, exposure, outcome)

title: Classify DAG nodes — classify_nodes
text: dag dagitty DAG object. exposure Optional– inferred DAG set; character; exposure node name (X). outcome Optional– inferred DAG set; character; outcome node name (Y).

title: Classify DAG nodes — classify_nodes
text: data.frame one row per node columns: variable (node name) logical flags: is_exposure, is_outcome, is_confounder, is_mediator, is_collider, is_descendant_of_outcome, is_descendant_of_exposure role (single primary label)

title: Classify DAG nodes — classify_nodes
text: label definitions confounder – ancestor X Y, descendant X mediator – descendant X ancestor Y collider – node 2 parents X / Y path (non-structural) descendant_of_outcome – descendant Y exposure / outcome labeled explicitly function call Notes: definitions, x exposure y outcome structural colliders calculated, define non-structural. structural colliders included boolean flag node may satisfy multiple properties; also return boolean flags property. role column gives single "primary" label using precedence defined .

title: Classify DAG nodes — classify_nodes
code: d1 <- dagitty::dagitty("dag { Z -> X; Z -> Y; X -> Y }") # confounder Z   classify_nodes(d1, exposure = "X", outcome = "Y") #> variable  role        X  Y  conf  med  col  dOut  dMed  dCol  dConfOn  dConfOff  NCT  NCO #> X         exposure    x                                                                   #> Y         outcome        x                                                                #> Z         confounder        x                                                                d2 <- dagitty::dagitty("dag { X -> M -> Y }") # mediator M   classify_nodes(d2, "X", "Y") #> variable  role       X  Y  conf  med  col  dOut  dMed  dCol  dConfOn  dConfOff  NCT  NCO #> X         exposure   x                                                                   #> Y         outcome       x                                                                #> M         mediator               x                                                          d3 <- dagitty::dagitty("dag { X -> C <- Y }") # collider C   classify_nodes(d3, "X", "Y") #> variable  role       X  Y  conf  med  col  dOut  dMed  dCol  dConfOn  dConfOff  NCT  NCO #> X         exposure   x                                                                   #> Y         outcome       x                                                                #> C         collider                    x    x

title: Pipe operator — %>%
text: See magrittr::%>% details.

title: Pipe operator — %>%
code: lhs %>% rhs

title: Pipe operator — %>%
text: lhs value magrittr placeholder. rhs function call using magrittr semantics.

title: Pipe operator — %>%
text: result calling rhs(lhs).

what: Print method for DAGassist reports — print.DAGassist_report
title: Print method for DAGassist reports — print.DAGassist_report
text: Nicely prints roles table, highlights potential bad controls, shows minimal/canonical adjustment sets, optionally shows formulas, renders compact model comparison (using {modelsummary} available, falling back {broom} basic coef() preview).

title: Print method for DAGassist reports — print.DAGassist_report
code: # S3 method for class 'DAGassist_report' print(x, ...)

title: Print method for DAGassist reports — print.DAGassist_report
text: x "DAGassist_report" object returned DAGassist(). ... Additional arguments (currently unused; present S3 compatibility).

title: Print method for DAGassist reports — print.DAGassist_report
text: Invisibly returns x.

title: Print method for DAGassist reports — print.DAGassist_report
text: printer respects verbose flag report: TRUE, includes formulas brief note variables added DAG logic (minimal canonical sets). Fitting errors shown inline per model column abort printing.

title: Print node classifications (aligned) — print.DAGassist_roles

title: Print node classifications (aligned) — print.DAGassist_roles

text: Removed compare_specs() print.compare_specs(), unused causing issues. Updated DESCRIPTION reference dagitty relevant article methods. CRAN re-submission.

title: DAGassist 0.2.3
text: Fixed imply logic. Previously, roles table, imply = FALSE display RHS variables, still assessed DAG-based relationships. Renamed desc(Y) IO, intermediate outcome Dropped desc(X) roles column Added dMed (descendant mediator) dCol (descendant collider) Updated documentation added vignettes last release CRAN submission.

title: DAGassist 0.2.2
text: Built pkgdown site several supporting vignettes. Significantly enhanced package documentation preparation CRAN release. Trimmed exported functions. Enhanced documented engine compatibility. Added omit_factors omit_intercept parameters. Reworked imply parameter restricts evaluation variables listed RHS. Fixed cluster argument bug.

title: DAGassist 0.2.1
text: variable labels across roles + model tables (LaTeX, .docx, .xlsx, .txt). unevaluated regressors note: list RHS terms DAG, shown outputs. keep factor dummies fixed effects default. better longtblr conversion/spacing; improved dynamic column width weighting line breaking long labels. auto-escape labels neat output. cleaner summaries label support. ## Changed consolidated helpers (assist_helpers.R + export_helpers.R). improved handling nuisance vars (FEs/tails). significantly improved documentation prep CRAN release. broader validation real replication data.

title: DAGassist 0.2.0
text: Renamed main entry point dag_assist() DAGassist().

title: DAGassist 0.2.0
text: Acyclicity checks clearer validation messages validate.R. Canonical adjustment sets alongside minimal sets. Support multiple minimal adjustment sets. Export LaTeX, Word (.docx), Excel (.xlsx), plain text (.txt). export_report() helper produce publication-grade, half-page robustness report single call. New imply parameter control DAG-implied covariate additions

title: DAGassist 0.2.0
text: Console report redesigned compact, readable tables Nicer console styling color

title: DAGassist 0.2.0
text: Fixed-effects / IV parts formulas (e.g., | region + time) preserved; validation looks pre-| part.
